paragraphs.text: Are you drinking because you're working long hours, or are you working long hours to justify drinking?
paragraphs.label: title

paragraphs.text: An international study released last week has identified that those who work more than 48 hours a week are 11% more likely to drink alcohol at risk levels than those working a standard week
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: The study was compiled by Finnish researchers, sampling 300,000 subjects across Europe, Australia and North America
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Health guidelines suggest that consumption of more than 14 drinks a week for women and 21 drinks for men poses a significant health risk
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: It's no surprise that it's a team of Finnish researchers who are examining the stats around unsafe drinking
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Nordic Finland may be a well-known haven of progressive social policy, with an enviable living standard, cradle-to-grave welfare and the world's best education system
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: but
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: there is one social problem the Finns have not yet licked
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Alcohol-related illnesses and incidents (including accidents, violence and suicide in which alcohol has factored) are the most common cause of death for both working age men and women there - and have been so for many years
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: The study is of useful consideration for Australians, of course
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: we're afflicted with alcohol problems of our own
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Australian research released only last July revealed up to 15 people die and more than 430 are admitted to hospital every day in Australia for alcohol-related reasons
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: That's 5,554 deaths and 157,132 hospital admissions a year, and four times the rate of the road toll
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: That working longer hours has a detrimental effect on an individual's health is well established
paragraphs.label: common-ground

paragraphs.text: Some have suggested from the results of the Finnish study that alcohol abuse is symptomatic of the "work hard, play hard" cultures around professions
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: - especially
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: because workers who shifted into longer-hours jobs during the study were 12% more likely to develop risky drinking habits as a result
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: Some have also suggested that the scarcity of leisure time for people who work long hours may result in habits of using alcohol as a concentrated form of relaxant
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: This is the opinion of Cassandra A  Okechukwu, assistant professor at the Harvard School of Public Health who declared of the Finnish findings that "people are self-medicating" due to work-life time constraints
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Alternatively, Dr Richard Wise, psychologist at Windana Drug and Alcohol Recovery, believes the relationship between work and drinking may be bi- directional
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: "As stress increases the activity of brain regions responsible for drug seeking and craving, stressful work is often 'addictive' in itself," says Wise
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: "This could be a self-perpetuating cycle- work causes stress, which renders people more prone to addictions to substances and work."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Significantly, the study itself does not claim to prove a causation- leaving open the possibility to discuss the pink elephant that lurks in the room behind all social discussions of problem drinking: the prevalent, if sometimes well-camouflaged, existence of actual alcoholics
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Writing in Business Insider, journalist Kevin Loria asked of the study:"Long hours may not cause dangerous drinking, but why is there a relationship between those two things at all?"
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: The answer is this: there is not one clear relationship, but potentially several
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: We know, for example, that those suffering active alcoholism seek out environments that facilitate and camouflage their drinking
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Why would the workplace be an exception?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Demanding jobs not only deliver alcoholics out of the worksite just in time for socially-acceptable drinking hours
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: but the stresses associated with long- hours work provide pretexts aplenty for "self-medicating" with booze
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Our community continues to excuse the practise of drowning one's sorrows
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: but
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: forgotten is that active alcoholics often go looking for sorrows in order to drown them
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The recovery community calls this phenomenon "drinking on it"
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: it's not hard to find a pretext to slam down some craved-for cold ones at the end of the day
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: if
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: you've just spent 10 hours at a desk
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: there' s one thing an alcoholic can use to deny the extent of their drinking`cond

paragraphs.text: it's the company of others who share the same problem
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The common logic of alcohol addiction brings alcoholics together in work environments as much as it does social ones
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Yet
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: while study after study identifies alcohol as a health, economic and justice burden on the community, and with the statistical acknowledgement that 3.7 million Australians are currently "drinking at long-term risky levels"
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: we're still - still - struggling to break our social addiction to the old stereotypes of alcoholics being weak-willed, staggering hobos rather than predominantly people with jobs, relationships and families who are sick with a dangerous medical problem
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: If
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: we choose to believe someone is drinking because they work long hours
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: we may be ignoring that someone is working long hours because it enables their drinking
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: A failure to identify behaviours symptomatic with alcoholism delays treatment and increases the danger alcoholics pose to themselves and to others
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Go back and look at the figures above: 5,500+ deaths and 150,000+ hospital admissions a year are not the result of mere casual tipples
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: They're the stats of widespread abuse that needs more than loose causation and euphemisms to treat it
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The Finnish study is valuable
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: because
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: it identifies a possible workplace component to the alcohol problem
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: With 3.7 million Australians presently at risk, the time is now to be realistic that a broader context of alcoholism exists
